awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: IRES - Track I: Brown Carbon Aerosol Formation by Photooxidation of Phenolic Compounds in Nanodroplets
awd_abstract_narration:
This IRES project provides experiences for 4-6 undergraduate researchers from the University of San Diego and Harvey Mudd College to spend 8-10 weeks researching brown carbon formation by aqueous photooxidation of atmospheric phenolic compounds. Four weeks of research will be conducted onsite at Universit? Paris Est ? Cr?teil (UPEC), where the cohort of undergraduate researchers will closely collaborate with their international mentors on a series of CESAM aerosol chamber experiments utilizing advance spectroscopic methods. After returning from France, the undergraduate research team will focus on the workup, interpretation, and presentation of chamber data, while continuing to interact with international mentors via video conferencing. Each participant will be involved in the project for at least one semester prior and two semesters subsequent to travel for training and further experimentation at their U.S. campuses. In total, 15 undergraduates over 3 years will participate in this international project and will be mentored by French scientists while gaining hands-on experience with advanced research tools. 
This IRES project is focused on atmospheric chemistry and will contribute to the better understanding of clean air and global warming.

Phenolic compounds, which are produced during biomass burning and from the oxidation of anthropogenic aromatic precursors, are believed to be significant sources of brown carbon aerosol when oxidized in cloud droplets, especially in the presence of iron (from dust) or nitrogen oxides (from combustion pollution).  However, multi-phase reactions of phenolic compounds have been studied mainly in bulk aqueous solutions rather than in more realistic nanodroplets, where photobleaching can become photobrowning and where reactivity is often accelerated, especially for surface-active oligomerizing species. The researchers will therefore study brown secondary organic aerosol (SOA) formation by phenolic precursor species in nanodroplet "cloud simulation" photooxidation experiments at the CESAM chamber in Paris, characterizing chemical and optical changes in aerosol particles before, during, and after cloud events. Particle browning will be monitored by CAPS-ssa and UV/visible spectroscopy of water-soluble OA as the reactants interact with seed aerosol, water droplets, and simulated sunlight in the pressure, temperature, and RH-controlled chamber. Particle-phase chemistry will be monitored by aerosol mass spectrometry (ACSM-TOF), and particle uptake and outgassing will be detected by high-resolution PTR-MS and long-path FTIR monitoring of gas- phase species.  This project will provide 15 diverse U.S. undergraduates with international research experiences at a state-of-the-art cloud chamber facility as the center of a 3-semester research experience for each participant.  Project activities will increase understanding of important sources of brown SOA, which will in turn allow this pollutant, and the adverse effects on human health and climate that it causes, to be minimized in a more cost-effective manner.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Brown Carbon Aerosol Formation by Photooxidation of Phenolic Compounds in Nanodroplets award was a 3 year grant from the National Science Foundation (NSF) program IRES program to support international, collaborative research on atmospheric aerosol chemistry in an atmospheric simulation chamber with undergraduate students at the University of San Diego and Harvey Mudd College. For each of three summers in 2019, 2021, and 2022 the PIs traveled to Paris, France with a cohort of 4-6 undergraduate students to investigate brown carbon formation by aqueous photooxidation of atmospheric phenolic compounds. In 2019 and 2021, four weeks of research were conducted onsite at Université Paris Est – Créteil (UPEC), where the cohort of undergraduate researchers collaborated with their international mentors on a series of CESAM aerosol chamber experiments utilizing advance spectroscopic and spectrometric methods. Students were trained in the operation, calibration, and interpretation of instrumental methods relevant to chemical, physical, and optical changes taking place in the chamber. In 2022, a cohort of 6 students participated in the ACROSS field campaign, where students were uniquely responsible for a measurement or instrumental method that was part of the larger campaign (a change in research plan was necessitated by the COVID-19 pandemic and delays in our planned chamber studies).

Phenolic compounds, which are produced during biomass burning and from the oxidation of anthropogenic aromatic precursors, are believed to be a significant source of brown carbon when oxidized in cloud droplets, especially in the presence of iron (from dust) or nitrogen oxides (from combustion pollution). However, multi-phase phenolic compound reactions have been studied mainly in bulk aqueous solutions rather than in more realistic nanodroplets, where photobleaching can become photobrowning and where reactivity is often accelerated, especially for surface-active oligomerizing species.

The unique CESAM chamber facility can generate photochemical “smog” and multiple cloud events in the same experiment and was thus essential for studying BrC formation via aqueous-phase photochemistry under realistic conditions.

The major scientific goals of the project were to leverage known brown carbon-producing gases emitted in wildfire smoke (i.e. syringol, pyrogallol, catechol, and guaiacol) to study how efficiently those gases are taken up into cloud droplets and onto aerosol particles and under what conditions, observe new product formation including new particulate matter and new light absorbing compounds, and to characterize the chemical composition, and changes to that composition, as clouds and light conditions in the chamber varied.
                             
Particle browning was observed over a wide range of conditions, but predominantly under wet or humid conditions, when the relative humidity was high enough for particles to deliquesce into droplets. Photoinduced browning was observed in multiple systems and was optically different from browning in dark reactions. While oxidants (hydrogen peroxide) aided in the formation of secondary material and brown products, additional oxidants were not required for browning reactions to occur as long as the chamber was lit. Online chemical measurements of particle composition incidate that the products formed with and without added oxidants were similar in some systems (e.g. syringol).

This project supported 26 future scientists by providing international research experiences at a state-of-the-art cloud chamber facility and an international field campaign for a diverse group undergraduate researchers. The undergraduate researchers were mentored by French scientists while gaining hands-on experience with advanced research tools. Project activities increased understanding of important sources of secondary organic aerosol (SOA), a dominant type of particulate air pollution.

A fuller understanding of SOA sources will allow this pollutant, and the adverse effects on human health that it causes, to be minimized in a more cost-effective manner. Additionally, project activities will reduce the uncertainties in projected climate change caused by the direct effects of anthropogenic emissions of brown carbon precursor gases.
